claim.hypotheses: H*: Firms that use names beginning with an A or a number will receive more complaints than firms not using names beginning with an A or a number.
claim.statement: Plumbers with names that begin with an A or a number receive more than five times as many complaints with the Better Business Bureau.

data.wave_or_subset: Plumbing firms in Illinois as of June 2008
data.notes: Data was matched using firm names and complaints were aggregated across multiple names for firms.

method.description: The study analyzes the relationship between firm name choice and the number of complaints received, using plumbing firms in Illinois. It uses firm-specific data on complaints, advertising expenditures, number of employees, and geographic location.
steps: Collect data on plumbing firms from ReferenceUSA and complaints from the Better Business Bureau.
Identify and aggregate data for firms with multiple names.
Match firms on variables such as phone numbers, fax numbers, websites, and addresses.
Conduct regression analysis to test the relationship between firm name characteristics and complaint rates.
method.models: Negative binomial regression for complaint counts, OLS for complaint rates per employee
method.outcome_variable: Number of complaints filed with Better Business Bureau
method.independent_variables: Firm name characteristics (e.g., starts with 'A' or number), advertising expenditures, employees, firm age, geographic location
method.control_variables: Employee count, firm age, advertising expenditures, geographic location

results.summary: Firms with names beginning with 'A' or a number receive significantly more complaints. This pattern is consistent across various specifications and controlled for confounding variables.

metadata.original_paper_title: “A” Business by Any Other Name: Firm Name Choice as a Signal of Firm Quality
